newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Strike threat recedes at Colombian Pacific port.
newsitem.headline: Strike threat recedes at Colombian Pacific port.

text.p: The threat of a renewed strike at Colombia's main Pacific coast port is receding as cargo operators begin to fulfill the terms of a deal signed in January, a regional union leader said Tuesday.
Dock workers at the port of Buenaventura had been due to meet Tuesday to decide whether to launch a fresh strike to press for improved wages, social security benefits and contract conditions.

But Nelson Amaya, regional leader of the Unitary Workers' Confederation (CUT), to which the main dockers' union SINTRAMARITIMO is affiliated, said the meeting had been postponed until Thursday because of the Easter break.

Dockers at Buenaventura staged a nine-day strike in January and paralyzed 60 percent of Colombia's key coffee shipments and all sugar exports. Amaya said last month that dockers were mulling fresh industrial action after many cargo operators at the port declined to meet the commitments undertaken in the accord hammered out to end the January stoppage.

"I have been talking to cargo operators at the port and asking them to pressure colleagues to meet the agreement. That seems to have produced good results and the situation is improving," Amaya told Reuters in a phone interview.
"There's a good possibility of avoiding the strike. I'm very optimistic," he added.

SINTRAMARITIMO represents about 2,000 workers at Buenaventura. The membership has been swelled to about 7,000 in the last month following Amaya's whirlwind recruitment drive at ports along Colombia's Caribbean coast.
